thread.title: Tatts director Brian Jamieson is having trouble keeping track of his stock
thread.title_full: Tatts director Brian Jamieson is having trouble keeping track of his stock

author: CBD
title: Tatts director Brian Jamieson is having trouble keeping track of his stock
text:
Illustration: John Shakespeare.
Tatts boss Robbie Cooke had the spit and polish out to present the company's full year results in the best light possible light on Thursday – it failed to distract Tatts watchers' from the latest shareholding "oversights" of veteran board member, Brian Jamieson .
Slipped in among Tatts financial announcements was the news that Jamieson has had a bit of trouble accounting for his shareholding interests in the lottery and wagering shop.
Late last year, Jamieson acquired an interest in 33,791 shares – representing a significant increase on his Tatts stake.
Tatts 'fessed up to this fact on Thursday, saying the tardy notice was an "administrative oversight".
Advertisement It hinted the director's unnamed wife was – how shall we put this delicately – a contributor to the problem.
It appears that Ms Jamieson received 3667 shares directly "from a deceased estate" and another 30,124 shares were transferred from the estate to a joint super fund with hubby.
Mind you, if Ms Jamieson was the dobbing kind she would probably point out that hubby – a former KPMG auditing veteran – has form when it comes to a lack of auditing oversight of his directors interests.
The last time he increased his shareholding, in 2009, Jamieson had to admit that he was months late notifying the ASX due to the purchase being made by a third party "in error".
Jamieson was not aware that his pension fund had participated in a dividend reinvestment plan and "he gave no instructions for this to occur."
His change of director's interest just prior to this incident, in 2007, corrected another administrative error.
He notified the ASX that the Tatts share interests he reported in 2005 – when it floated – had been in error.
Jamieson reported an interest in 29,000 shares held in the name of the D. Jamieson super fund, but reported that he was not a member of the fund and had no interest in the shares. "This was an inadvertent and erroneous disclosure," he reported.
Maybe Jamieson should stick to buying Tatts lottery tickets in future.
Corporate baggage While Qantas boss, Alan Joyce , was crowing about the cost cutting that helped its momentous recovery from financial penury – including significant bloodshed at the front line with 5000 staff in the firing line – there was one particular sector of the airline that did not appear to be pulling its weight.
Corporate – which the airline describes as the "centralised management and governance of the Qantas Group", weighed in with a $163 million loss for the flying 'roo, equalling its performance for the 2014 financial year.
CBD hopes that will be reflected in bonuses for those in corporate HQ when the annual report is released.
Copping it The victims of the Commonwealth Bank's financial planning fiasco have watched its compensation process proceed at a glacial pace, but there have been signs of movement behind the scenes.
While CBA boss, Ian Narev , was preparing to host the financial press at a bank dinner Wednesday night, the bank's wealth arm was digesting the news that Harry Mitchell , head of Commonwealth Financial Planning (CFP), had departed.
"It's with mixed emotions that I advise that Harry Mitchell ... no longer works for the CBA Group," said Marianne Perkovic , who goes by the title of Executive General Manager Advice.
"I would like to thank Harry for his contribution to CFP over the past three years, and wish him the best for his future endeavours," she said of the former Scottish cop.
In an interview with Money Management two years ago, Mitchell made it clear he saw himself as a new broom at the financial planning arm, sweeping out any culture of bad advice.
"It's going to be really uncomfortable for people who don't want to do the right thing and I'm OK with that," he said at the time.
Judging by his LinkedIn profile, he has not left for a fresh career opportunity.
"I am currently seeking new career opportunities," reads the opening line of the profile baring his name.
Got a tip? ckruger@fairfaxmedia.com.au
